Context:
Program Name: Business Administration – Finance
Code: B130
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,888.00 *
International Tuition: $17,925.00 **
School: Accounting & Finance
Location: St. James Campus
Program Description: Prepares students with specialized knowledge and skills for careers in the financial services sector.
Skills gained after completion: Help clients achieve their life goals through financial advising, preparing comprehensive financial plans, analyzing financial reports, advising on tax obligations and risk management, and having a broad understanding of all areas of business.
Related Programs: Financial Planning (Postgraduate) (B407), Business Administration – Finance (with work experience) (B150), Business – Accounting (B103)

Context:
The Centre for Business at George Brown College offers a Business Administration – Finance program, which is part of the School of Accounting and Finance. This program is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP), making George Brown one of only two colleges in Ontario with ACBSP accreditation. Students have the option to apply for the program with work experience by applying to B150.

Graduates of this advanced diploma program may be eligible for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program. Career opportunities include financial advisor/planner, financial services representative, customer service representative, and investment advisor. Graduates may also pursue credentials or certifications such as Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) and Certified Financial Planner (CFP®) through FP Canada. A degree requirement is being introduced for those wishing to become a CFP professional.

For more information regarding field education, eligibility, and related credentials or certifications, please contact Katherine Friesen (kfriesen@georgebrown.ca), Tracey Britt (tbritt1@georgebrown.ca), or Carolyn Fallis (cfallis@georgebrown.ca).

The Business Administration – Finance program has earned international recognition from ACBSP, with fourteenth programs at the Centre for Business being accredited in total. George Brown College is now one of only two colleges in Ontario to have earned this accreditation.

Students in this program can obtain the knowledge and skills necessary to pursue careers in the financial services sector. Career options include financial advisor/planner, financial services representative, customer service representative, and investment advisor.

Graduates of the Business Administration – Finance advanced diploma may be eligible for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program. Eligibility will be assessed based on completion of the entire program, individual courses, and/or program GPA.

Additionally, graduates may wish to pursue other credentials or certifications in the financial services sector, such as the Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) and Certified Financial Planner (CFP®) designations through FP Canada. However, a degree requirement is being introduced for those wishing to become a CFP professional. Please contact the provided email addresses for more information.

Context:
The text provides information about various designations/certifications that can be obtained outside of George Brown College, including the Canadian Securities Course (CSC) through the Canadian Securities Institute and the Life License Qualification Program (LLQP) through Oliver’s Learning. Students in the Business Administration – Finance program may be eligible for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program at George Brown.

To graduate from the B130 program, a total of 39 courses are required. The Financial Services specialization includes 35 mandatory courses, 1 Business elective, and 3 General Education electives. The Financial Planning specialization consists of 34 mandatory courses, 2 Business electives, and 3 General Education electives. Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to certain courses, which do not count towards the 39 courses required for graduation and will incur additional charges.

Students must complete three General Education courses chosen from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). It is necessary to make up any failed or dropped courses before being eligible to graduate, and some making-up courses may be offered in the evening through Continuing Education.

No specific program names or start/end dates were mentioned in the text.

The text also mentions pre-requisites for some of the courses such as Principles of E-Business (COMP 1113) and Microeconomics (ECON 1031). There is a Field Education opportunity in Co-operative Education and Career Development, which is by application only.

Additionally, the text mentions that George Brown College has articulation agreements with several universities in Canada, the United States, and abroad, which may give students credit for their college diploma.

The program learning outcomes include skills related to financial record processing and maintenance, financial report analysis, financial planning, marketing strategy development, professional networking, and Canadian context analysis.

Context:
Program Offered: The text mentions a program focused on professional networking and business relationships in the finance sector. Individuals enrolled in this program will analyze and evaluate economic variables, legislation, ethics, technology, and the environment within a Canadian context. They will develop strategies for personal and professional development, coordinating team projects using project management principles.

Costs: The text provides information on domestic and international tuition fees for programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024. Domestic tuition is $3,888.00, while international tuition is $17,925.00. Additional costs, which include materials, student services, and ancillary fees, are also mentioned but their exact amounts vary depending on the program start date. These fees do not include books that students must purchase separately.

Exams: The program prepares students to write industry-credentialing exams such as Canadian Securities Course I and II (CSC I and CSC II), Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) Exam, Certified Financial Planner® (CFP®) Exam, and Life License Qualification Program (LLQP). Fees for external exams are not included in the program fees and students should visit specific websites for information regarding exam dates and fees.

Financial Assistance: The text mentions that this program is available but no further details about financial assistance were provided.

Context:
The text provides information on various aspects of applying to George Brown College for both domestic and international students. Here is the extracted information:

1. Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP funding.
2. Admission Requirements: Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, English (C or U) at grade 12 level, and Math (C, M or U) at grade 11 or 12 levels. Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits.
3. Course Exemptions: College and university credits may qualify for exemptions. Check out the transfer guide for more information.
4. English Language Proficiency: Proficiency in English communications is necessary for success in the program. Review the English proficiency requirements.
5. International Students: Visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
6. How to Apply: Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
7. Contact Us: For domestic student inquiries about admission requirements or admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at [admissions@georgebrown.ca](mailto:admissions@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Admissions section. International student inquiries can be directed to the international recruitment representatives specializing by country.
8. Information Sessions: Sign up for an upcoming on-campus information session.
9. Domestic Student Admissions: Contact the Admissions Office for queries about domestic admissions, deadlines, or the admissions process.
10. International Student Admissions: Contact one of the international recruitment representatives specializing by country.
